body:
This is a difficult problem to solve. The library messes with the type structure. The method in question looks like this:

``` java
@WithBridgeMethods({void.class})
public GHIssueComment comment(String message) throws IOException
```

This makes it impossible for Byte Buddy to build bridge methods as they are required by the Java-specification. A `void` type can simply not be assigned to a `GHIssueComment` type. cglib "solved" this problem by ignoring bridge methods alltogether but all in all, there is no good solution to this. The mocked class is simply not legal Java code.

I need to look into a better bridge method building mechanism without breaking the type validation. The problem is also the use of adapter methods; Byte Buddy would not know how to convert bridged types. I think the best way would be to simply ignore any incompatible bridge types.

You confirmed my fears, I was kinda prudent when I said unusual. Could we fail more graciously?

For `GhRepository` the problem is a bit different as the byte code is generated, but objenesis fails to instantiate the mock class `VerifyError` thrown by the JVM.

I added a filter to Byte Buddy that throws out bridge methods that are incompatible to the bridged methods signature. Its already fixed on master. I will make a new release some time soon, this makes the error go away. As bridge methods are inherited, it does neither break runtime behavior.

The verifier error comes from Byte Buddy casting an `int` to an `Object` which is again a failed attempt to implement an illegal bridge method. This is also fixed with the added filter.

PS: Adding such bridge methods also breaks Javac. Adding such methods synthetically is generally not a good idea for non-final types.

When I discovered that bridge hack to maintain backward compatibility, I thought this is a bad idea.
I'm even less enticed to use this library.

Thanks @raphw, it seems mockito brings a whole world of weirdness to bytebuddy ðŸ˜‰

I understand the general intend to retain backwards compatibility but this is a general problem in Java and the hack might seem intelligent in the beginning but it is really problematic and might also confuse reflection. It would work much better if it was only used for final types.

I am glad I find these things out, encountering these issues makes Byte Buddy better in the long run ;)

Thanks guys for investigating the problem! Let me clarify the resolution. Although some options to fix the problem exist, there is no good solution. Therefore, some classes from github-api are not currently mockable with Mockito 2.
- Can we close this ticket for the time being? We can revisit when there are more use cases.
- Is there a way to fail more intelligently and provide better insight to the user?
Let's wait for @raphw to release a new ByteBuddy version before closing.
I fixed this already. Byte Buddy now skips incompatible bridges. Will release soon.

issue.title: Realm is still not mockable with Mockito after 2.2.2 change

repository.name: realm-java
repository.description: Realm is a mobile database: a replacement for SQLite & ORMs

issue.body:
So, as discussed here: https://github.com/realm/realm-java/issues/3869 and implemented since 2.2.2 (https://github.com/realm/realm-java/pull/3911/files), the removal of the final modifier would allow mocking Realm without the use of PowerMock. Needless to say, after spending so much time trying to make Realm + PowerMock + Roboelectric work (and failing to do so), I was ecstatic to hear about aforementioned changes. But...

It was still impossible to mock Realm.class:
`Mockito.mock(Realm.class)` would end up
```
org.mockito.exceptions.base.MockitoException: 
Mockito cannot mock this class: class io.realm.Realm.

Mockito can only mock non-private & non-final classes.
If you're not sure why you're getting this error, please report to the mailing list.


Java               : 1.8
JVM vendor name    : Oracle Corporation
JVM vendor version : 25.112-b15
JVM name           : Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM
JVM version        : 1.8.0_112-b15
JVM info           : mixed mode
OS name            : Windows 7
OS version         : 6.1
```

My guess is it's because Realm.class still has a private constructor.

Am I doing something wrong and there is a more elaborate way to set things up? Is there still a way to mock stuff without PowerMock? If not, what is the point of https://github.com/realm/realm-java/pull/3911/files change?

Things I used in my code: 
- `io.realm:realm-gradle-plugin:2.3.0-SNAPSHOT`
- `org.mockito:mockito-core:2.4.0`
- `com.google.dagger:dagger:2.8`
- `org.robolectric:robolectric:3.1.4`

Oh, and all the production and test code is written in Kotlin.

issue.title: Unable to mock GHObject#id
